elements.content: Three new heterometallic formate coordination polymers formulated as [Na2Co(HCOO)4]∞ (1), [NaCo(HCOO)3]∞ (2), and [Na2Co7(HCOO)16]∞ (3) were obtained by adjusting the solvent and ratio of the reactants. In 1, a (4,4) cobalt formate layer is formed and the sodium ions connect the layers to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework. In 2, each formate ligand binds two Co2+ and two Na+ ions with a syn,syn,anti,anti coordination mode to form a chrial network with 4,6-connected topology. 3 is a Na+-ion-linked 3D framework based on the cobalt formate layer, which has a 10-membered metal ring. Magnetic studies indicate the existence of ferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1, while dominating antiferromagnetic couplings in 2 and 3.

In 1, a (4,4) cobalt formate layer is formed and the sodium ions connect the layers to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework. elements.content: Through variation of the metal ratio and solvents, the structure and magnetism of three new heterometallic sodium(1+)−cobalt(2+) formate coordination polymers with different ratios of Co2+ and Na+ ions have been well tuned.
elements.clean_text: Through variation of the metal ratio and solvents, the structure and magnetism of three new heterometallic sodium(1+)-cobalt(2+) formate coordination polymers with different ratios of Co2+ and Na+ ions have been well tuned.

elements.content: In recent years, the investigation of coordination polymer-based magnets and the magnetostructural relationship had become the focus of intense researches for their unusual structures and physical properties. Although significant progress has been made in practical and theoretical approaches, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers with desirable magnetic properties is still a tremendous challenge. The key point in constructing new molecule-based magnets with desired structures and properties is how to judiciously choose the appropriate bridging ligands, which can help to realize the fine-tuning of the local interactions between spin carriers and form the targeted product via self-assembly between paramagnetic metal centers and ligands. A good candidate as a short bridging ligand that could mediate magnetic coupling effectively, a formate anion with diverse binding ability is used extensively to construct molecule magnetic materials. Over the last decades, a huge number of formatometal complexes with diverse bridging modes such as μ2-O/syn,syn/anti,anti/syn,syn,anti/syn,anti,anti and syn,syn,anti,anti modes of formate and various types of structures from a zero-dimensional cluster to one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and three-dimensional (3D) networks have been reported. A variety of magnetic phenomena, such as ferromagnetic behavior, antiferromagnetic ordering, spin canting, etc., have also been observed in such complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the investigation of coordination polymer-based magnets and the magnetostructural relationship had become the focus of intense researches for their unusual structures and physical properties. Although significant progress has been made in practical and theoretical approaches, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers with desirable magnetic properties is still a tremendous challenge. The key point in constructing new molecule-based magnets with desired structures and properties is how to judiciously choose the appropriate bridging ligands, which can help to realize the fine-tuning of the local interactions between spin carriers and form the targeted product via self-assembly between paramagnetic metal centers and ligands. A good candidate as a short bridging ligand that could mediate magnetic coupling effectively, a formate anion with diverse binding ability is used extensively to construct molecule magnetic materials. Over the last decades, a huge number of formatometal complexes with diverse bridging modes such as μ2-O/syn,syn/anti,anti/syn,syn,anti/syn,anti,anti and syn,syn,anti,anti modes of formate and various types of structures from a zero-dimensional cluster to one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and three-dimensional (3D) networks have been reported. A variety of magnetic phenomena, such as ferromagnetic behavior, antiferromagnetic ordering, spin canting, etc., have also been observed in such complexes.

elements.content: Among various metal formates, cobalt-based complexes are attractive because of their large single-ion anisotropy (good candidate for single-molecule and single-chain magnets) and the flexibility of the cobalt ion in adopting different coordination modes, in terms of both the coordination number and geometry. Furthermore, the magnetic behaviors could be more diverse in cobalt-involved heterometallic systems. In most of the reported heterometallic systems, the metal ions were paramagnetic 3d–3d or 3d–4f heterometal. Little attention has been paid to introduce diamagnetic alkali-metal ions in such systems. The introduction of alkali-metal ions may provide more variability to construct magnetic complexes with complicated structures, fantastic topologies, and particular coordination geometries, which may lead to unpredictable and interesting magnetic phenomena.

In most of the reported heterometallic systems, the metal ions were paramagnetic 3d-3d or 3d-4f heterometal. Little attention has been paid to introduce diamagnetic alkali-metal ions in such systems. The introduction of alkali-metal ions may provide more variability to construct magnetic complexes with complicated structures, fantastic topologies, and particular coordination geometries, which may lead to unpredictable and interesting magnetic phenomena.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis and structures of three new heterometallic formate complexes with different Co/Na ratios formulated as [Na2Co(HCOO)4]∞ (1), [NaCo(HCOO)3]∞ (2), and [Na2Co7(HCOO)16]∞ (3). The structures of these complexes were found to be affected by the used solvents and Co/Na ratios of the reactants. Magnetic measurements revealed that the interaction between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1 was ferromagnetic, while dominating antiferromagnetic couplings were found in 2 and 3. Furthermore, 3 was an antiferromagnet showing a spin-flop transition with critical field at ca. 4000 Oe.

The structures of these complexes were found to be affected by the used solvents and Co/Na ratios of the reactants. Magnetic measurements revealed that the interaction between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1 was ferromagnetic, while dominating antiferromagnetic couplings were found in 2 and 3. Furthermore, 3 was an antiferromagnet showing a spin-flop transition with critical field at ca. 4000 Oe.

elements.content:
All of the chemicals used for the synthesis were of analytical grade and were commercially available.

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA for a copper-target tube and a graphite monochromator. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) Fourier transform IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a standard TGA–DTA analyzer under a nitrogen flow at a heating rate of 2 °C min–1 for all measurements. Simulation of the PXRD spectra was done by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.

Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All of the chemicals used for the synthesis were of analytical grade and were commercially available.

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA for a copper-target tube and a graphite monochromator. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) Fourier transform IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a standard TGA-DTA analyzer under a nitrogen flow at a heating rate of 2 °C min-1 for all measurements. Simulation of the PXRD spectra was done by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.

elements.content: Magnetic data were collected using well-crushed crystals of the samples on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. The data were corrected using Pascal’s constants to calculate the diamagnetic susceptibility, and an experimental correction for the sample holder was applied.

elements.content: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), NaHCOO (3 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 12 h, and pure primrose-black crystals were collected with ca. 20–25% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C4H4CoNa2O8 (1): C, 16.86; H, 1.41. Found: C, 16.95; H, 1.72.

elements.content: Method A: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol), NaHCOO (2 mmol), 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L; 1.5 mmol), and DMF:MeOH = 1:1 (10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 12 h, and pure primrose-pink crystals were collected with ca. 20–25% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O with complex Na2CoL2 as commensalism. Method B: Similar to method A, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol), NaHCOO (0.4 mmol), NH4HCOO (2.4 mmol), and MeOH (10 mL) were used as reactants, and the yield is ca. 30–35% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C16H16Co7Na2O32 (3): C, 16.30; H, 1.37. Found: C, 16.62; H, 1.65.

elements.content: It is worth noting that the solvent and the ratio of the formate anion with Na+ and Co2+ ions are vital to obtaning the three complexes. Reacting sodium formate and Co2+ using DMF as the solvent with a Co2+/Na+ ratio of 1:2 yielded 1, while changing the Co2+/Na+ ratio to 1:1 yielded 2. However, using mixed solvents (DMF:MeOH = 1:1) or MeOH as solvents and adjusting Co2+/Na+ ratio of 7:2, 3 was obtained (3 could be synthesized in two different methods as mentioned above). The IR spectra for the three complexes are given in Figure S1 in the (SI), in which the absorption band ∼2900 cm–1 belongs to a C–H stretching vibration and the bands ∼1600, ∼1300–1400, and ∼800 cm–1 belong to O–C–O stretching and deformation vibrations. TGA results (Figure S2 in the ) indicate that these complexes are stable until about 250 °C.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1–3 were collected on a Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω-scan mode. The program Rigaku CrystalClear was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All of the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program). Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Table shows the crystallographic data and structure-processing parameters. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1-3 were collected on a Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω-scan mode. The program Rigaku CrystalClear  was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All of the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program). Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Table  shows the crystallographic data and structure-processing parameters. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (see Table ) and has a 3D framework structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two unique formate anions, one Na+ and half of a Co2+ ion. The Co1 ion locates in the inversion center with a compressed octahedral coordination configuration, while the Na+ ion is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms (Figure S3 in the ). As shown in Figure , each Co1 is coordinated by six different formate anions with two kinds of configurations, of which one kind of formate anion links four Na+ ions and one Co2+ ion with a bridge-chelate mode and the other kind of formate anion takes a syn,syn,anti,anti mode to link two Na+ and two Co2+ ions. All of the Co2+ ions are linked in the equatorial plane with the second kind of formate to form 2D (4,4) layers (Figure b) and the first kind of formate anions take the apical positions of Co2+ ions. The cobalt(2+) formate layer is anionic for the superfluous coordination of formate anions. The charge is balanced by the Na+ ions between the layers to form sandwich-like layers (Figure c), which are connected by the linkage of Na+ ions and formate anions on both sides of the layers and finally form a 3D framework (Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (see Table ) and has a 3D framework structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two unique formate anions, one Na+ and half of a Co2+ ion. The Co1 ion locates in the inversion center with a compressed octahedral coordination configuration, while the Na+ ion is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms (Figure S3 in the ). As shown in Figure , each Co1 is coordinated by six different formate anions with two kinds of configurations, of which one kind of formate anion links four Na+ ions and one Co2+ ion with a bridge-chelate mode and the other kind of formate anion takes a syn,syn,anti,anti mode to link two Na+ and two Co2+ ions. All of the Co2+ ions are linked in the equatorial plane with the second kind of formate to form 2D (4,4) layers (Figure b) and the first kind of formate anions take the apical positions of Co2+ ions. The cobalt(2+) formate layer is anionic for the superfluous coordination of formate anions. The charge is balanced by the Na+ ions between the layers to form sandwich-like layers (Figure c), which are connected by the linkage of Na+ ions and formate anions on both sides of the layers and finally form a 3D framework (Figure d).

elements.content: 2 crystallizes in the cubic space group I213, and its asymmetric unit contains half of a formate anion, with one-third of the metal position M1.5+ being occupied by Co2+ and Na+ ions together with a 1:1 ratio. The topology structure of 2 is the same as that of the reported manganese formate, but their crystal structures have some differences. In the manganese formate, the Mn2+ and Na+ ions take two different positions, but in 2, the Co2+ and Na+ ions are disordered in one position. The M1.5+ ion has an octahedral configuration coordinated by six oxygen atoms (Figure a). The formate anions bridge four M1.5+ in a syn,syn,anti,anti mode with the bond angle of M–O–M = 95.77(5)°. In that way, the M1.5+ ions are connected to 12 neighbors by 6 μ–4 formate anions to form a 3D network, in which the metal ions can be divided into two equal sets of nets linked by the syn,anti formate (Figure b). In each set, the M1.5+ ions are connected to six neighbors with the same M···M distance of about 5.59 Å (Figure c), and the two sets of nets share the same formate anions, forming the final structure of 2 (Figure d). From a topological view, in each syn,anti formate bridged net, the M1.5+ ions could be considered as a 6-connected node and both of the two nets could be simplified as a lcy topology net (Figure a,b). Furthermore, both of the two copies of nets have the same chirality. The M1.5+ ions of the lcy nets connect directly to the nearest M1.5+ ions in the other copy of the lcy net by double μ2-oxygen atoms of the formate anions. If neglecting the linkage of the carbon atoms of the formate, a (10,3)-a net would be generated (Figure c). However, taking the connections of the formate between the M1.5+ ions into account, 2 could be viewed as a 4,6-connected net with a notation symbol of {43;62;8}3{49;66}2 (Figure d).

elements.content: 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit of 3 contains eight formate anions, one Na+ ion, and four Co2+ ions in which Co1 locates in the inverse center, being only half-occupied. Both Na+ and Co2+ ions in 3 are six-coordinated by the oxygen atoms from formate anions. The Co2+ ions show octahedral configurations, while the Na+ ions take trigonal-prismatic configurations. The formate anions in 3 could be classified as five different types depending on their coordinated environments. As shown in Figure.a, the first type containing C1 and C5 takes a syn,syn,anti mode to bridge Co1, Co2, and Co3 or Co1, Co3, and Co4. The second type takes a syn,syn,anti,anti mode to link three Co2+ and one Na+ ions, in which the formate containing C2 and C7 bridges three Co2+ ions in a syn,syn,anti mode while the formate containing C3 bridges three Co2+ ions in a syn,anti anti mode. The third type of formate anion containing C6 links two Co2+ ions in a syn,syn mode and two Na+ ions in an anti,anti mode. The fourth type of formate anion containing C4 coordinates to two Co2+ and one Na+ ions in a syn,syn,anti mode. The last type of formate containing C8 bridges Co2 and Co4 with O15, leaving the other oxygen atom O16 uncoordinated. Then the structure of 3 could be comprehended as follows: the first type of formate anion bridges Co2+ ions to form a 10-membered cobalt ring (Figure a), and the rings are interconnected by sharing part of the linkage to form a 1D chain, which is further expanded via the formate anions containing C3 to form a 2D layer (Figure b). Finally, a 3D structure is formed by connection of the Na+ ions between the 2D Co2+ layers (Figure c).

elements.content: In a comparison to other alkali anions like K+ or ammonium, which take the role of template in a metal formate system, Na+ has smaller size, which results in shorter Co···Co distances in order to have the maximum effective packing. Thus, in 1, the formate anions adopt a syn,anti mode to link Co2+ ions, not like in the nicolite-, perovskite-, and chiral-related metal formates templated by big cations in which the formate takes an anti,anti mode. In 2 and 3, there are less Na+ ions in the structure; thus, the syn,syn,anti,anti, syn,anti,anti, and syn,syn,anti formate anions present link Co2+ ions with more small Co···Co distances.
elements.clean_text: In a comparison to other alkali anions like K+ or ammonium, which take the role of template in a metal formate system, Na+ has smaller size, which results in shorter Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances in order to have the maximum effective packing. Thus, in 1, the formate anions adopt a syn,anti mode to link Co2+ ions, not like in the nicolite-, perovskite-, and chiral-related metal formates templated by big cations in which the formate takes an anti,anti mode. In 2 and 3, there are less Na+ ions in the structure; thus, the syn,syn,anti,anti, syn,anti,anti, and syn,syn,anti formate anions present link Co2+ ions with more small Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were carried out on well-crushed crystalline samples of 1–3 (phase purity of the samples confirmed by PXRD; see Figure S4 in the ), and different magnetic behaviors were found to exist in the three complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Magnetic measurements were carried out on well-crushed crystalline samples of 1-3 (phase purity of the samples confirmed by PXRD; see Figure S4 in the ), and different magnetic behaviors were found to exist in the three complexes.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 are shown in Figure as χm T vs T and M/NμB vs H plots, assuming a crystallographic unit containing one Co2+ ion for the molar weight. The χm T values first increase smoothly up to 3.62 cm3 K mol–1 from room temperature to 130 K, and then the value decreases to a minimum value of 3.14 cm3 K mol–1 at 15 K before increasing quickly. The best-fit parameters from the magnetic data recorded at 100–300 K through the Curie–Weiss law (Figure S5 in the ) are θ = 7.43 K and C = 3.43 cm3 K mol–1. The Weiss constant for one magnetically isolated high-spin Co2+ ion with spin–orbit coupling is about −20 K. Thus, the positive Weiss constant of 1 suggests ferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Co2+ ions in the layer structure of 1. The minimum of the χm T vs T plots is due to the cooperative effects of the ferromagnetic interactions between Co2+ ions and spin–orbit coupling of the single Co2+ ion. The syn,anti formate should be expected to mediate weak ferromagnetic interactions between Co2+ ions. Also, the field-dependent magnetizations at 2 K (Figure , inset) clearly corroborate the ferromagnetic coupling between Co2+ ions. On the other hand, the M/NμB curve does not follow the Brillouin function. With an increase of the field, it reaches a saturation value quickly at about 1 T, and the M/NμB value at 5 T is close to 3.3NμB. The zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetization curves under 100 Oe are completely identical, excluding the long-range ferromagnetic order in the ferromagnetic layers being well separated by the Na+ ions (Figure S6 in the ).

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 are shown in Figure as χm T vs T and M/NμB vs H plots, assuming a crystallographic unit containing one Co2+ ion for the molar weight. The χm T curve starts to decrease from room temperature upon cooling and reaches 0.81 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The best-fit parameters from the magnetic data in the temperature range 50–300 K through the Curie–Weiss law (Figure S5 in the ) are θ = −23.75 K and C = 3.49 cm3 K mol–1. The Weiss constant is less than −20 K, indicating antiferromagnetic interactions conducted by the syn, syn,anti,anti formate anions between Co2+ ions. The field-dependent magnetizations at 2 K (Figure , inset) corroborate the antiferromagnetic coupling because the curve shows an increasing trend along with an increase of the field almost linearly without saturation.

elements.content: For 3, the χm T vs T and M/NμB vs H, assuming one Co2+ ion for the molar weight are shown in Figure . Starting from room temperature, the χm T values smoothly decrease until about 10 K, and then it shows a small rise before finally dropping. The best-fit parameters from the magnetic data from 50 to 300 K through the Curie–Weiss law (Figure S5 in the ) are θ = −25.88 K and C = 3.73 cm3 K mol–1. Different from that of 1 and 2, the χm vs T plots of 3 show a peak at about 2.5 K, suggesting an antiferromagnetic order in 3 below 2.5 K (Figure S7 in the ). The increase in χm with a decease of the external field and the χm T vs T plots at low temperature may be due to slight impurities in the samples. The field-dependent magnetizations at 2 K (Figure , inset) corroborate the antiferromagnetic interactions at low temperature, which has a value of 2.04 NμB at 5 T without saturation. It is worth noting that there is an inflection in the M vs H plots. The inflection is obvious, and the first derivative shows a clear maximum at ca. 4000 Oe, indicating that above that field 3 underwent a spin-flop transition from an antiferromagnetic phase to a paramagnetic phase.

elements.content: In 1–3, the Co2+ ions linked by the formates in five different modes (Table ), in which the syn,syn,anti,anti/syn,anti,anti, and syn,syn,anti modes could be viewed as a combination of four basic modes: syn,syn, anti,anti, syn,anti, and μ2-O modes, which conduct magnetic coupling, respectively. The syn,syn mode conducts strong antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co2+ ions, while the anti,anti, and syn,anti modes mediate weak ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic coupling, and the magnetic interactions conducted by the μ2-O mode depend on the Co–O–Co angle with a critical value of 90°. The antiferromagnetic interactions conducted by formate in the four basic modes are familiar. Thus, the antiferromagnetism of 2 and 3 is common, while the ferromagnetic interaction in 1 is infrequent but not surprising in formate or carboxylate complexes. The magnetic interactions conducted by different carboxylates between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1–3 and some reported complexes have been summarized in Table .

The syn,syn mode conducts strong antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co2+ ions, while the anti,anti, and syn,anti modes mediate weak ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic coupling, and the magnetic interactions conducted by the μ2-O mode depend on the Co-O-Co angle with a critical value of 90°. Three new heterometallic formate coordination polymers formulated as [Na2Co(HCOO)4]∞ (1), [NaCo(HCOO)3]∞ (2), and [Na2Co7(HCOO)16]∞ (3) have been obtained by adjusting the solvent and ratio of the reactants. The ferromagnetic interactions exist between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1, while dominating antiferromagnetic couplings in 2 and 3 were found.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new heterometallic formate coordination polymers formulated as [Na2Co(HCOO)4]∞ (1), [NaCo(HCOO)3]∞ (2), and [Na2Co7(HCOO)16]∞ (3) have been obtained by adjusting the solvent and ratio of the reactants. The ferromagnetic interactions exist between adjacent Co2+ ions in 1, while dominating antiferromagnetic couplings in 2 and 3 were found.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), NaHCOO (3 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 12 h, and pure primrose-black crystals were collected with ca. 20–25% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C4H4CoNa2O8 (1): C, 16.86; H, 1.41. Found: C, 16.95; H, 1.72.

Synthesis of <bold>2</bold>

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), NaHCOO (1 mmol), and DMF (10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 12 h, and pure primrose-black crystals were collected with ca. 20–25% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C3H3CoNaO6 (2): C, 16.61; H, 1.39. Found: C, 16.38; H, 1.12.

Synthesis of <bold>3</bold>

Method A: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol), NaHCOO (2 mmol), 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2L; 1.5 mmol), and DMF:MeOH = 1:1 (10 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 12 h, and pure primrose-pink crystals were collected with ca. 20–25% yield based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O with complex Na2CoL2 as commensalism. Method B: Similar to method A, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol), NaHCOO (0.4 mmol), NH4HCOO (2.4 mmol), and MeOH (10 mL) were used as reactants, and the yield is ca. 30–35% based on Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. Calcd for C16H16Co7Na2O32 (3): C, 16.30; H, 1.37. Found: C, 16.62; H, 1.65.

cln_elements.content:
It is worth noting that the solvent and the ratio of the formate anion with Na+ and Co2+ ions are vital to obtaning the three complexes. Reacting sodium formate and Co2+ using DMF as the solvent with a Co2+/Na+ ratio of 1:2 yielded 1, while changing the Co2+/Na+ ratio to 1:1 yielded 2. However, using mixed solvents (DMF:MeOH = 1:1) or MeOH as solvents and adjusting Co2+/Na+ ratio of 7:2, 3 was obtained (3 could be synthesized in two different methods as mentioned above). The IR spectra for the three complexes are given in Figure S1 in the (SI), in which the absorption band ∼2900 cm–1 belongs to a C–H stretching vibration and the bands ∼1600, ∼1300–1400, and ∼800 cm–1 belong to O–C–O stretching and deformation vibrations. TGA results (Figure S2 in the ) indicate that these complexes are stable until about 250 °C.

The magnetic properties of 1 are shown in Figure as χm T vs T and M/NμB vs H plots, assuming a crystallographic unit containing one Co2+ ion for the molar weight. The χm T values first increase smoothly up to 3.62 cm3 K mol–1 from room temperature to 130 K, and then the value decreases to a minimum value of 3.14 cm3 K mol–1 at 15 K before increasing quickly. The best-fit parameters from the magnetic data recorded at 100–300 K through the Curie–Weiss law (Figure S5 in the ) are θ = 7.43 K and C = 3.43 cm3 K mol–1. The Weiss constant for one magnetically isolated high-spin Co2+ ion with spin–orbit coupling is about −20 K. Thus, the positive Weiss constant of 1 suggests ferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Co2+ ions in the layer structure of 1. The minimum of the χm T vs T plots is due to the cooperative effects of the ferromagnetic interactions between Co2+ ions and spin–orbit coupling of the single Co2+ ion. The syn,anti formate should be expected to mediate weak ferromagnetic interactions between Co2+ ions. Also, the field-dependent magnetizations at 2 K (Figure , inset) clearly corroborate the ferromagnetic coupling between Co2+ ions. On the other hand, the M/NμB curve does not follow the Brillouin function. With an increase of the field, it reaches a saturation value quickly at about 1 T, and the M/NμB value at 5 T is close to 3.3NμB. The zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetization curves under 100 Oe are completely identical, excluding the long-range ferromagnetic order in the ferromagnetic layers being well separated by the Na+ ions (Figure S6 in the ).

The magnetic properties of 2 are shown in Figure as χm T vs T and M/NμB vs H plots, assuming a crystallographic unit containing one Co2+ ion for the molar weight. The χm T curve starts to decrease from room temperature upon cooling and reaches 0.81 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The best-fit parameters from the magnetic data in the temperature range 50–300 K through the Curie–Weiss law (Figure S5 in the ) are θ = −23.75 K and C = 3.49 cm3 K mol–1. The Weiss constant is less than −20 K, indicating antiferromagnetic interactions conducted by the syn, syn,anti,anti formate anions between Co2+ ions. The field-dependent magnetizations at 2 K (Figure , inset) corroborate the antiferromagnetic coupling because the curve shows an increasing trend along with an increase of the field almost linearly without saturation.
